case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Respondents

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 6 of 1965 filed by the State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 6 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 17, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 215 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 17, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 215 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 17, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 215 of 1963. Ram Reddy and K. Javaram, for the appellant.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court set aside the conviction of the respondents on January 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: challenges the order dated January 17, 1964, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, setting aside the conviction of the respondents, for an offence under s. 4  I   a , of the Andhra Pradesh  Andhra Area  Prohibition Act, 1937  Act X of 1937 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Respondents were found transporting fifty gallons of arrack in a bullock cart on the early morning of June 10 1962.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, the respondents were found transporting, in a bullock cart, on the early morning of June 10 1962 fifty gallons of arrack. It is the case of the prosecution that the prohibition staff found, on the day in question, a bullock cart, driven by the first respondent, in which the fifty gallons of arrack were found in 13 tins.

facts.text: Bullock cart driven by the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: a bullock cart, driven by the first respondent, in which the fifty gallons of arrack were found in 13 tins. Accordingly, they were prosecuted for an offence under s. 4   1   a , of the Act.

facts.text: Fifty gallons of arrack found in 13 tins in the bullock cart.

anchor.surface_text: in which the fifty gallons of arrack were found in 13 tins. Accordingly, they were prosecuted for an offence under s. 4   1   a , of the Act. All the respondents substantially denied, having committed the offence, with which they were charged.

facts.text: Respondents prosecuted for offence under s. 4(1)(a) of the Andhra Pradesh (Andhra Area) Prohibition Act, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, they were prosecuted for an offence under s. 4   1   a , of the Act. All the respondents substantially denied, having committed the offence, with which they were charged. The prosecution let in the evidence of the Prohibition Sub- Inspector, P.W.1, and another petty officer of the prohibition staff, P.W.4.

facts.text: All respondents denied committing the offence.

anchor.surface_text: All the respondents substantially denied, having committed the offence, with which they were charged.

facts.text: Prohibition Sub-Inspector (PW1) and petty officer (PW4) smelled arrack from the bullock cart.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of these two witnesses, was to the effect that when the bullock cart, in question, came near them, there was a smell of arrack. In particular, P.W.4 has stated that the tins, which were in the bullock cart, were pierced with bayonet, and when smelt, they gave a strong smell of arrack.

facts.text: Tins in bullock cart pierced with bayonet by PW4, strong smell of arrack.

anchor.surface_text: In particular, P.W.4 has stated that the tins, which were in the bullock cart, were pierced with bayonet, and when smelt, they gave a strong smell of arrack. To corroborate the evidence of these two officers, the other witnesses,. P.Ws. 2 and 3, who were stated to have witnessed this occurrence, along with the prohibition party, were also examined.

facts.text: PW2 and PW3 witnessed strong smell of arrack and 12 tins pierced with bayonet.

anchor.surface_text: They stated that when the bullock cart came near them, they got a strong smell of arrack, and that the 12 tins were pierced with bayonet ends and their contents verified.

facts.text: Trial Court convicted respondents under s.4(1)(a), sentenced each to rigorous imprisonment for six months.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the trial Court accepted the evidence of the prosecution, found the respondents guilty of the offence under s. 4  I   a  of the Act, and sentenced each of them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for six months.

facts.text: Respondents challenged conviction before Sessions Judge, Kurnool.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents challenged their conviction, before the learned Sessions Judge, Kurnool.

facts.text: Sessions Judge confirmed the conviction of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge in the end, confirmed the conviction of the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents filed revision to Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents carried the matter further, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, in revision.

facts.text: High Court set aside conviction holding no proper proof that commodity was arrack.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has accepted the plea of the respondents that, in this case, there has been no proper proof that the commodity that was found to be transported, was arrack.

facts.text: No appearance on behalf of respondents in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did not appear. ... There is no appearance, on behalf of the respondents, before, us, in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds prosecution failed to establish commodity was liquor under s.3(9).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the circumstances of this case, the High Court was perfectly justified in holding that the prosecution has not established that the respondents are guilty of an offence, under s. 4  1   a  of the Act.

facts.text: No chemical analysis of the seized commodity.

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution should have got the commodity examined, by a Chemical Examiner, and, inasmuch as that procedure has not been adopted, the High Court ultimately, set aside the conviction of the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents suggested in cross-examination that identification of persons in bullock cart not possible at night.

anchor.surface_text: Only some of the witnesses have been cross-examined, and the respondents, have suggested to them that during that hour of the night, it would not have been possible for them to identify the persons, who were stated to have been in the bullock cart.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held prohibition officer's smell experience sufficient proof.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the prohibition officer must be considered to have got sufficient experience of smelling and knowing whether a liquid was arrack, or not, and, inasmuch as he has deposed that the liquid was found to be arrack, by smell, that statement can be accepted as proof of the nature of the liquid

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment by Vaidialingam, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Vaidialingam, J.

facts.text: P. Ram Reddy argued for appellant State.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Reddy and K. Javaram, for the appellant. The respondent did not appear.

facts.text: Respondents denied that arrack was seized from them.

anchor.surface_text: Even otherwise, it will have to be noted that all of them have, categorically, denied the offence and have also stated in general terms, that no arrack was seized from them.

anchor.surface_text: Merely trusting to the smelling sense of the Prohibition Officers, and basing a conviction, on an opinion expressed by those officers, under the circumstances, cannot justify the conviction of the respondents. In our opinion, better proof, by a technical person,

In our opinion, better proof, by a technical person, who has considered

arguments.claim: Baidyanath Mishra v. State of Orissa not applicable as arrack lacks characteristic appearance and scent of opium
Prosecution not established necessary ingredients of offence under s.4(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: During the trial, however the question appears to have been raised, among other contentions, that the prosecution has not established the necessary ingredients for establishing that the respondents have committed the offence, under s. 4 1   a , of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC held prosecution failed to establish guilt

arguments.claim: Lack of effective challenge to witnesses does not absolve prosecution from proving offence ingredients

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the circumstance, pointed, out by the learned counsel, will not absolve the prosecution from establishing the ingredients of the offence, for justifying the conviction of the respondents.

holdings.text: The High Court was perfectly justified in holding that the prosecution has not established that the respondents are guilty of an offence under s. 4(1)(a) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the circumstances of this case, the High Court was perfectly justified in holding that the prosecution has not established that the respondents are guilty of an offence, under s. 4  1   a  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to prove seized article was liquor under s.3(9) despite smell evidence; no technical proof provided.

holdings.text: To establish guilt under s.4(1)(a), the prosecution must prove (i) the seized article is liquor under s.3(9) and (ii) the accused transported it.

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose, the prosecution will have to establish two things  i  that the article seized from the accused is liquor, under s. 3  9  of the Act and  ii  that the accused transported the same. E

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation requires proof of both elements for contravention of transport prohibition.

holdings.text: General statements by prohibition officers of strong smell of alcohol from pierced tins is not satisfactory evidence that the article is liquor.

anchor.surface_text: Except for a general statement, contained in the evidence of the witnesses, particularly P.Ws. 1 and 4, that there was a strong smell of alcohol, emanating from the tins, which were pierced ,open,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Smell evidence alone inadequate when accused deny offence; lacks objectivity.

holdings.text: Better proof by a technical person from a scientific point of view is not only desirable but even necessary to establish the seized article is liquor.

anchor.surface_text: Merely trusting to the smelling sense of the Prohibition Officers, and basing a conviction, on an opinion expressed by those officers, under the circumstances, cannot justify the conviction of the respondents. In our opinion, better proof, by a technical person,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subjective sensory evidence insufficient; objective chemical analysis required for reliable proof of liquor nature.

holdings.text: Lack of effective challenge to prosecution witnesses does not absolve prosecution from establishing ingredients of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the circumstance, pointed, out by the learned counsel, will not absolve the prosecution from establishing the ingredients of the offence, for justifying the conviction of the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution bears burden of proof irrespective of defence cross-examination strategy.

holdings.text: Observations in Baidyanath Mishra v. State of Orissa do not apply as arrack lacks the characteristic appearance and scent of opium.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on facts: opium identifiable by senses, unlike arrack requiring analysis.

precedents.citation: Baidyanath Mishra v. The State of Orissa l

anchor.surface_text: Baidyanath Mishra v. The State of Orissa l . In that case, the question was as to whether the appellants, therein, were in possession of opium, so as to make them liable for an offence. The Opium Act of 1878, defin

precedents.case_name: Baidyanath Mishra v. The State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Opium possesses characteristic appearance and scent allowing identification by sight and smell without chemical analysis when not diluted
precedents.cited_holding: It is true that opium is a substance which once seen and smelt can never be forgotten because opium possesses a characteristic appearance and avery strong and characteristic scent. It is possible for people to identify opium without having to subject the product to a chemical analysis.
